Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: A social media post about your cause is currently going viral, and now is the perfect moment to add a comment with more information.
Story: I stare at my phone, the notification count climbing higher—my post about environmental justice is finally gaining traction. This is the moment I’ve been waiting for, the chance to educate thousands, maybe more, if I can just add the right comment now. But as I start typing, my son tugs at my sleeve, his eyes wide with hope. “Did you get the Nintendo, Mom? You promised.” I remember the look on his face last week, the excitement in his voice. I know how much he’s been looking forward to it, and I know how tight money is this month. I promised him, and I want to keep that promise. But if I don’t seize this moment online, the momentum for my cause might fade. My heart pounds as I weigh the cost of the Nintendo against the fleeting window of attention for my activism. Both roles demand my full attention, and I feel myself pulled in two, unable to let either go.
